questions.text: If the tRNA has the sequence 5’-GAC-3’, what codon on mRNA it would  recognize?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

C: 5’-GUC-3’

The codon on mRNA is read in 5’ to 3’ direction. The anticodon on tRNA match the codon in antiparallel direction. Hence the sequence 5’-GAC-3’ on anticodon arm of tRNA is matched with 5’-GUC-3’ codon on mRNA

choices.text: Increased water permeability in the collecting ducts

questions.text: Which of the following will occur in a dehydrated person deprived of water for more than 24 hours?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Increased water permeability in the collecting ducts

In a dehydrated person, increased plasma osmolality and decreased ECF volume will result in increased ADH secretion. ADH increases the insertion of acquporin 2 in the luminal membrane of cells of the collecting duct increasing their permeability to water and therefore, increasing the water reabsorption.

Decreased ECF volume increases the plasma renin activity, increases ADH but decreases ANP

questions.text: The GFR of a 50-year-old man decreases by 50% and remains at that level. Plasma concentration of which of the following substances will be increased to the greatest extent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

creatinine

Creatinine is freely filtered, not reabsorbed and slightly secreted. Excretion of creatinine is, therefore, dependent almost entirely on glomerular filtration. A decrease in GFR will therefore, cause the greatest increase in plasma concentration of creatinine.  

Plasma concentrations of glucose, potassium and sodium are closely regulated by multiple mechanisms that keep them relatively constant even when the GFR falls to very low levels

questions.text: Cholera toxin acts by disrupting which of the following in the intestinal epithelial cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
zonula occludens
Vibrio cholerae releases cholera toxin (CT) and zona occludens toxin (ZOT). CT binds to GM1 ganglioside receptors on the apical surface. The massive secretion of salt and water in cholera-induced diarrhoea involves binding of cholera toxin (CT) to ganglioside GM1 in the apical membrane of intestinal epithelial cells, translocation of the enzymatically active A1-peptide across the membrane, and subsequent activation of adenylate cyclase located on the cytoplasmic surface of the basolateral membrane

questions.text: Which of the following is not produced by osteoblasts?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Pyrophosphate

Alkaline phosphate from osteoblasts neutralize pyrophosphate, an inhibitor of hydroxyapatite crystallization. Neutralization of pyrophosphate permits the precipitation of calcium salts into collagen fibres. 

RANKL (ligand) is secreted by osteoblasts and binds to the RANK receptor on osteoclast precursor and mature osteoclast cells.

Osteoprotegerin is the decoy receptor which binds and thereby opposes RANK ligand activity. Binding of parathormone with its receptors on osteoblasts decreases the secretion of osteoprotegerin and thereby, increases Rank ligand activity

questions.text: All are true for sublingual route except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

All drugs can be given

Ref: Read the text below   

Sol:

Sublingual route of administration

  • The tablet or pellet containing the drug is placed under the tongue or crushed in the mouth and spread over the buccal mucosa.
  • Only the lipid soluble and non-irritating drugs can be administered by this route
  • Absorption is rapid and action can be produced in minutes
  • Action can be easily terminated by spitting the drug after the desired effectis achieved.
  • Liver is bypassed with this route, thus the drugs with high first pass metabolism can be easily given by this route.
  • Drugs given by this rout are : GTN, buprenorphine, desamido-oxytocin

questions.text: Which of the following alpha blocker is useful in BPH?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Prazosin

Ref: Read the text below   

Sol:

BPH 
It is  treated to relax the prostate, and finasteride or dutasteride to decrease the mass of the prostate with following-

  1. alpha-blocker terazosin
  2. prazosin
  3. doxazosin
  • Prazosin is a peripheral acting alpha-adrenergic blocker which is primarily used to treat hypertension.
  • Phentolamine is an α-adrenergic blocker used for-
    -controlled hypotension,
    -treatment of perioperative hypertensive crisis that may accompany pheochromocytoma removal and prevention or treatment of dermal necrosis .
    -It can also be use to do sloughing after intravenous administration or extravasation of barbiturate or sympathomimetic.
  • Phenoxybenzamine is an irreversible, non-competitive α1 and α2 adrenergic receptor antagonist which decreases vascular resistance, lowering both the supine and the standing blood pressure.
  • Tolazoline is a competitive α1 and α2 adrenergic blocking agent. It is also used to  relaxes vascular smooth muscles as it  produces a peripheral vasodilatation.

questions.text: Which one of the following statements is a characteristic of both nitroglycerin and amyl nitrite?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

They may cause orthostatic hypotension

Ref: Read the text below   

Sol:

  • Both organic nitrates and nitrites relax smooth muscle and produce venodilation, resulting in orthostatic hypotension.
  • Therefore, patients should sit down before administering sublingualnitroglycerin or inhaling amyl nitrite.
  • Only nitrites such as amyl nitrite can cause methemoglobinemia and are therefore used to treat cyanide poisoning; methemoglobin has increased affinity for cyanide compared with normal hemoglobin.
  • Because amyl nitrite is a volatile liquid that must be administered by inhalation, it has no value in the prophylaxis of angina

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Rifampicin?

Rifampicin

  • It is an effective liver enzyme-inducer which promotes the upregulation of hepatic cytochrome P450 enzymes such as CYP2C9 and CYP3A4
  • It also increases the rate of metabolism of many other drugs.
  • It reduces the efficacy of hormonal contraception.
  • It is used in prophylactic therapy but not for treatment intead against Neisseria meningitidis (meningococcal) infection

questions.text: Which of the following rates is related to identifying “at risk” group?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Option 1 - Specific death rate Mortality Indicators Specific Death Rate Cause/ disease/ age/ sex/ ..... Specific divided by mid year population Is a rate Advantage Helps in identifying “AT RISK group” Helps in comparison between different causes within the same population Proportional Mortality Rate Deaths due to a specific cause/ disease/ age/ sex/ ...... Per 100/ per 1000 total deaths Is a proportion Advantage Simplest measure of estimating disease burden Indicates magnitude of preventable mortality Used when population is not known Case Fatality Rate 1. Killing power/ severity of a disease with no time interval 2. Can be used to measure benefits of new therapy i.e, any therapy which prevents mortality will reduce case fatality 3. Related to virulence of organism 4. Name is a rate but actually a proportion 5. Complement of survival rate 6. CFR = 1 – survival rate 7. Disadvantages: 1. Time interval is not specified 2. Useful only for acute diseases

choices.text: The intact tympanic membrane protects the round window and directs sound energy to the ossicular chain and oval window

questions.text: Choose the incorrect statement regarding “Sound transmission in the middle ear”
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The physiological ratio of tympanic membrane to oval window surface area is about 21 : 1 .

Ref: Read the text below

Sol:

  • Sound energy is preferentially transmitted to the oval window. The eardrum acting as a baffle preventing sound reaching the round window.
  • The axis of rotation being a line joining the anterior process of the malleus and short process of the incus.
  • With low intensity sounds the axis is near the posterior margin of the footplate. At high intensity the axis runs longitudinally through the footplate. The latter affords greater protection of delicate inner ear structures.
  • The anatomical ratio is 21:1 but the tympanic membrane is fixed at its periphery. Only two thirds is available for physiological vibration. Therefore the physiological ratio is about 14: 1 .
  • This allows some degree of impedance matching between the external air and inner ear fluids.

questions.text: A 22 year old woman presents with 6 weeks history of malaise and weight loss. On clinical examination she has palmar hyperpigmentation. With which investigation should she be followed up?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Primary hypoadrenalism results in increased synthesis and secretion of ACTH from the pituitary gland. Due to the co-secretion of melanocyte-stimulating hormone as part of the larger prohormone (pro-opiomelanocortin; POMC), hyperpigmentation occurs, classically of the palmar creases. Secondary hypoadrenalism due to pituitary pathology, with resultant low ACTH levels, is associated with skin pallor. The dexamethasone suppression test forms part of the workup for suspected Cushing’s syndrome.

Flow chart for a suspected case of adrenal insufficiency is given below

questions.text: A 75 year old woman with metastatic non-small cell lung cancer is considering palliative chemotherapy. Her cancer was discovered when she had a CT scan because of a combination of weight loss, smoking habit and finger clubbing. She has developed increasingly painful wrists. What is the most likely cause for this problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The most likely cause is HAOP, a painful periostitis of the distal radius and ulna. Bone metastases are possible but less likely. Hypercalcaemia can certainly cause bone pain and measuring calcium levels is always indicated when there is bone pain. Horner’s syndrome can cause pain in the inner aspect of the arm and small muscle wasting in the hand

questions.text:
A 38 year old man is referred with a history of polydipsia and polyuria passing over 3 L of urine in 24 hours. He undergoes a water deprivation test followed by post desmopressin test, which shows the following results

The urine osmolality is improved following the administration of desmopressin suggestive of a central cranial cause. In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, urine osmolality would show little improvement following administration of desmopressin.In psychogenic polydipsia urine osmolality will increase to more than 300 after water deprivation test

questions.text: Hypothyroidism can result in which of the following cardiovascular effects?

Correct Answer (A) 

Cardiovascular effects of hypothyroidism are-

  • Reduced ventricular diastolic relaxation
  • Increased peripheral vascular resistance leading to increased DBP
  • Hypercholesterolaemia

questions.text: A 53 year old woman whose thyroid function tests have been stable and within the normal range on 200 µg of levothyroxine for the last 6 months is found to have a TSH <0.01mIU/L. questions.text: A previously healthy 48 year old man complaint of acute pain, swelling and redness of the right ankle with no obvious trigger factor. Weight is 94 kg. He has a history hypertension treated with thiazides. He drinks beer each night. What is the most likely diagnosis?

The pattern of involvement and acute onset is not consistent with rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis or osteoarthritis.

questions.text: On routine health check-up a 30 year old man was found to have hematuria in urine analysis but he denies passing blood in urine. He is asymptomatic with no personal or family history of renal disease. His BP is 126/68 mmHg. Investigations reveal: urinalysis: blood +, protein negative; serum creatinine 1.13 mg/dL; eGFR 95 mL/min/1.73 m2. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Asymptomatic microscopic haematuria is a suggestive of IgA nephropathy.
In Alport’s disease- deafness and a family history of renal disease will be present.
Membranous nephropathy presents with proteinuria. 
Bladder tumor-age is usually >40 years and gross hematuria will be seen

questions.text: A 17 year old male complains of decreased urinary output and swelling over face. There is history of dysentery 5 days back. His BP is 164/92 mmHg ,blood urea 126 mg/dL; serum creatinine 7 mg/dL; sodium 129 mmol/L; potassium 6.4 mmol/L; haemoglobin 6.8 g/dL; platelet count 36000/mm3; blood film shows schistocytes; urinalysis: blood 1+, protein negative; stool cultures negative for Escherichia coli O157. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The combination of low haemoglobin, low platelets and schistocytes on blood film suggest microangiopathic haemolytic anaemia, which may be due to haemolytic uremic syndrome or thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. The antecedent bloody diarrhoea and predominant renal versus neurological complications are consistent with HUS rather than TTP. The negative E. coli O157 stool cultures do not rule out HUS as they have been taken after the diarrhoeal phase of the illness

questions.text: Major criteria for blood culture for infective endocarditis is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 

Major criteria for blood culture are-

a) Typical microorganisms consistent with IE from 2 separate blood cultures: Viridans streptococci, Streptococcus bovis, HACEK group, Staphylococcus aureus and enterococci.

b) Microorganisms consistent with IE from persistently positive blood cultures, defined as follows:

i. At least 2 positive cultures of blood samples drawn >12 hours apart; or

ii. All of 3 or a majority of 4 separate cultures of blood (with first and last samples drawn at least 1 hour apart)

c) Single positive blood culture for Coxiella Burnetii or antiphase I IgG antibody titer >1:800

questions.text: A 30 year old patient had stab wound injury on the back resulting in Brown Sequard Syndrome. Which sensation will be lost on the side of injury?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

The features of Brown Sequard syndrome are:

  • Damage to corticospinal tracts - Ipsilateral spastic paralysis below the level of the lesion and Babinski sign ipsilateral to the lesion (abnormal reflexes and Babinski sign may not be present in acute injury)
  • Damage to posterior white column - Ipsilateral loss of vibration and position sensation below the level of the lesion
  • Damage to spinothalamic tracts - Contralateral loss of pain, touch and temperature sense 2-3 segments below the level of the lesion

questions.text: What will be the alveolar arterial oxygen gradient with the given values-Alveolar exchange ratio 0.8, PaO2 49 mmHg and PaCO2 48 mmHg
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
PAO2 = (Patm - PH2O) FiO2 - PaCO2/RQ
Patm is the atmospheric pressure (at sea level 760 mm Hg), PH2O is partial pressure of water (approximately 45 mm Hg). FiO2 is the fraction of inspired oxygen. PaCO2 is partial pressure of carbon dioxide (in normal physiological conditions around 40 to 45 mmHg).

questions.text: A patient presented with hematuria and acute renal failure. Renal biopsy showed crescentic glomerulonephritis and IF showed C3 and IgG deposition. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

PSGN produces such a picture of ARF with crescentic GN and IgG + C3 deposits on IF. The deposits are subepithelial. Other cases mainly produce proteinuria with or without hematuria and do not involved crescent formation. The types of crescentic GN are-

Type 1 (anti-glomerular basement membrane [GBM] disease) presents with linear deposits of immunoglobulin G (IgG)

Type 2 (immune-complex mediated) presents with granular deposits of immunoglobulin

Type 3 (pauci-immune) presents with few or no immune deposits, antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibody-associated small vessel vasculitis (SVV) that may be renal-limited or part of a systemic disease-granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

Type 4 includes combinations of types 1 and 3

Type 5 is ANCA-negative, pauci-immune renal vasculitis

questions.text: A 12 year old boy presented with contractures affecting the knee and ankle joint muscles. Natural progression of disease revealed humeral and peroneal muscle weakness later spreading to limb girdle distribution.Which of the following statement is false regarding this myopathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 

Clinical diagnosis is Emery-Dreifuss muscular dystrophy (EDMD). Important points are-

  • Can be X-linked recessive, AD or AR
  • Has a triad of 3 things
    • Slowly progressive muscular weakness and wasting affecting scapular and humeral muscles: Symmetric in nature
    • Early contractures of the elbow, ankle and posterior neck
    • Cardiac conduction defects often with cardiomyopathy, which can lead to sudden death
  • Cardiac disease is the cause of death in EDMD

questions.text: A 75 year old smoker presented with ST elevation MI affecting anterolateral wall. Clinically patient is in shock. Intra-Aortic Balloon Pulsation followed by PCI done. You are asked to calculate  IABP-SHOCK II score to predict mortality. All the following  parameter will be included except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A) 

. IABP-SHOCK II score predicts prognosis based on six variables:

  • age >73 years
  • prior stroke
  • glucose at admission >10.6 mmol/L (191 mg/dL)
  • creatinine at admission >132.6 μmol/L (1.5 mg/dL)
  • thrombolysis in myocardial infarction flow grade after PCI<3 
  • serum lactate> 5 mmol/L

questions.text: A patient with severely itchy lesions with few blisters on his elbow comes to you. His histology is as shown. The diagnosis is:

These neutrophilic abscesses are called microabscesses.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy had a gradually progressive plaque on a buttock for the last 3 years. The plaque was 15 cm in diameter, annular in shape, with crusting and induration at the periphery and scarring at the center. The most likely diagnosis is

questions.text: Patient comes with fever and malaise since 2 weeks, joint pain and tender erythematous nodules on shin. The diagnostic histology would be

Erythema nodosum is a septal panniculitis associated with joint pains, red tender nodules on the shin and fever. There is no vasculitis. The commonest cause is a streptococcal infection. Other causes are TB, sarcoidosis, drugs, Behcet’s disease, and inflammatory bowel diseases

questions.text: What is the most common cause of graft failure in transplants?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Human leukocyte antigen (HLA) are the most common cause of graft rejection. Their physiological function is to act as antigen recognition units. They are highly polymorphic (amino acid sequence differs widely between individuals) HLA-A, -B, -C (class I), and -DR, -DP and -DQ (class II) are most important in organ transplantation

questions.text: A capsule endoscopy is being planned for a patient with Crohn’s disease. Which of the following is an absolute contraindication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Small bowel stricture is an absolute contraindication. Barium follow – through or small bowel MRI is advocated to rule out stricture before capsule endoscopy. Severe gastroparesis and pseudo – obstruction are relative contraindications

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of distributive shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Distributive shock describes the pattern of cardiovascular responses characterising a variety of conditions, including septic shock, anaphylaxis and spinal cord injury. Inadequate organ perfusion is accompanied by vascular dilatation with hypotension, low systemic vascular resistance, inadequate afterload and a resulting abnormally high cardiac output

questions.text: The suture material shown below commonly used for closing abdomen is completely absorbed in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Completely absorbed in 180 days. Tensile strength is 70% at two weeks and 50% at 4 weeks

questions.text: All of the following are features of Ebb phase except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The ebb phase begins at the time of injury and lasts for approximately 24–48 hours. It may be attenuated by proper resuscitation, but not completely abolished. The ebb phase is characterised by hypovolaemia, decreased basal metabolic rate, reduced cardiac output, hypothermia and lactic acidosis. The predominant hormones regulating the ebb phase are catecholamines, cortisol and aldosterone (following activation of the renin–angiotensin system).

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department with a 4-h history of acute, severe left scrotal pain. Examination reveals a high-riding left testicle and scrotal exploration was done. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The undescended testis is more prone to testicular torsion, largely as a consequence of a developmental abnormality between the testis and its mesentery. Exploration for torsion should be performed through a transverse scrotal incision. If the testis is viable when the cord is untwisted, it should be prevented from twisting again by fixation with three non-absorbable sutures between the tunica albuginea of the testis and the scrotal raphe. The use of absorbable sutures risks the possibility of recurrent torsion at some time in the future. The other testis should also be fixed because the anatomical predisposition is likely to be bilateral

choices.text: Most common location is the posterior triangle of neck
Diagnostic imaging modality is CT scan

questions.text: A neonate presented with a cystic swelling in the neck which was brilliantly transilluminant. Which of the following is true about the swelling?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Cystic hygromas usually present in the neonate or in early infancy, and occasionally may present at birth and be so large as to obstruct labour. The cysts are filled with clear lymph and lined by a single layer of epithelium with a mosaic appearance. Swelling usually occurs in the neck and may involve the parotid, submandibular, tongue and floor of mouth areas. The swelling may be bilateral and is soft and partially compressible, visibly increasing in size when the child coughs or cries. The characteristic that distinguishes it from all other neck swellings is that it is brilliantly translucent. MRI is the diagnostic modality of choice in cystic hygroma. Definitive treatment involving complete excision of the cyst at an early stage is best if possible

questions.text: Gall bladder carcinoma is M1 stage when which of the following lymph nodes are involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The draining nodal basin for gallbladder cancer includes the hepatoduodenal ligament. From there, affected lymph nodes may include periaortic nodes near the celiac axis or pancreaticoduodenal nodes around the superior mesenteric artery. Because the venous drainage of the gallbladder includes direct venous tributaries into the liver parenchyma, these tumors may spread directly into segment IV of the liver. Transperitoneal spread is also common and can progress to carcinomatosis

questions.text: A child presents with non bilious vomiting and abdominal distension. USG abdomen is done. What is the length of the pylorus required to make a diagnosis of infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
A pyloric muscle thickness of 4 mm and a length of 15 to 18 mm is required to make a diagnosis of infantile pyloric hypertrophic stenosis

questions.text: The Grynfeltt – Lesshaft triangle is bounded by all except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
The superior lumbar triangle of Grynfeltt – Lesshaft is bounded by the 12th rib superiorly, internal oblique inferiorly and the sacrospinalis medially

questions.text: All are true for the following stone except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Cystine stones are often multiple, are very hard and are radio-opaque. Family members should be screened with a sodium cyanide–nitroprusside test. Cystine stones are relatively resistant to ESWL due to their hardness. 6-mercaptopropionyl glycine (MPG) is an alternative therapy to D-penicillamine and has fewer side effects. A cystine calculus occurs only in the presence of cystinuria and is radio-opaque because of its high sulfur content. A triple phosphate calculus is composed of ammonium, magnesium and calcium phosphates and occurs in urine infected with urea-splitting organisms

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of massive transfusion?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Complications from massive transfusion include:

● coagulopathy;

● hypocalcaemia;

● hyperkalaemia;

● hypokalaemia;

● hypothermia.

In addition, patients who receive repeated transfusions over long periods of time (e.g. patients with thalassaemia) may develop iron overload. (Each transfused unit of red blood cells contains approximately 250 mg of elemental iron.)

questions.text: Indication for surgery in a case of adrenal incidentaloma
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Surgery for hormonally active tumours and masses carrying significant risk for malignancy.
Most incidentalomas can be removed laparoscopically, except for those displaying obvious malignant features on imaging.
Remove all incidentalomas measuring >5 cm and to strongly consider removal of those measuring 3–5 cm, follow up with CT, every 6-months for <3 cm.
Indications of surgery in Incidentaloma 3–5 cm
1. Suspicious imaging characteristics (heterogeneity, high attenuation, or irregular margins) 
2. Young age
3. Few surgical risk factors
4. Interval tumor growth
5. Patient preference

choices.text: Mucosal incision should be closed in all

questions.text: All are true about POEM except?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Peroral esophageal myotomy (POEM) has shown promise as a NOTES treatment for esophageal achalasia. In this procedure, a 1.5- to 2-cm  mucosotomy is created within the anterior esophagus 10 cm proximal to the gastroesophageal junction. A submucosal tunnel is then created using a combination of electrocautery, hydrodissection, and carbon dioxide insufflation. The scope is advanced beyond the gastroesophageal junction, and a circular myotomy is performed avoiding disruption of the longitudinal fibers. The mucosotomy is then closed using endoscopic clips With use of an operating endoscope, the mucosa of the oesophagus is divided around the mid to distal. Through this tunnel, muscular layer of the distal esophagus, LES, and cardia is visualised and divided. G.A. is required in all cases

questions.text: A patient presents with recurrent pain abdomen. A diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis due to pancreas divisum is made. Which of the following procedures is used in patients with pancreas divisum with chronic pancreatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The minor papilla is substantially smaller than the major papilla (and many of these patients probably have papillary stenosis). A large volume of secretions flowing through a narrow papilla probably leads to incomplete drainage, which may then cause obstructive pain or pancreatitis. Certainly, in patients with idiopathic recurrent pancreatitis, pancreas divisum should be excluded. Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stenting of the minor papilla may relieve the symptoms. The place of duodenum preserving pancreatic head resection and longitudinal pancreaticojejunostomy (Frey procedure) for painful chronic pancreatitis associated with pancreas divisum has been considered.
Beger’s procedure - The operation, developed by Dr. Beger in Germany, involves removing almost all of the head of the pancreas, saving the duodenum, stomach and bile duct.
A distal splenorenal shunt procedure (DSRS), also splenorenal shunt procedure and Warren shunt, is a surgical procedure in which the distal splenic vein (a part of the portal venous system) is attached to the left renal vein (a part of the systemic venous system)

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents to the emergency room complaining of redness and pain in her right foot up to the level of the midcalf. She reports that her right lower extremity has been swollen for at least 15 years, but her left leg has been normal. On physical examination, she has a temperature of 39°C (102.2°F) and the right lower extremity is nontender with nonpitting edema from the groin down to the foot. There is cellulitis of the right foot without ulcers or skin discoloration. The left leg is normal. Which of the following is the most likely underlying problem?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
This patient’s underlying problem is unilateral primary lymphedema. Lymphedema is classified as primary when the etiology is unknown. Hypoplasia of the lymphatic system of the lower extremity accounts for more than 90% of cases of primary lymphedema. If edema is present at birth, it is referred to as congenital; if it starts early in life (as in this woman), it is called praecox; if it appears after the age of 35 years, it is tarda

questions.text: Which of the following is the most appropriate indication for placement of IVC filter?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The Greenfield filter pictured on the x-ray is used to interrupt migration of emboli to the lungs from the veins below the level of the filter. It is indicated in patients who sustain a recurrent pulmonary embolus despite adequate anticoagulant therapy or in patients with pulmonary emboli who cannot receive anticoagulants because of a contraindication (eg, bleeding ulcer, intracranial hemorrhage). The filter is not used in patients who sustain a single pulmonary embolus. It is placed in the inferior vena cava just below the renal veins and therefore would not be effective for emboli that arise cephalad to its position. Despite the hypercoagulable state seen in some patients with metastatic pancreatic cancer, anticoagulation can still be used as a first-line defence

choices.text: Symptoms appeared or got aggravated in last one year.
No criterion for other psychotic disorders are met

questions.text: All of the following statements about “attenuated psychosis syndrome” are true except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Insight is absent
Solution: 
ATTENUATED PSYCHOSIS SYNDROME:
•    It is a new diagnostic category included in DSM-5.
•    It is a syndrome characterized by subthreshold psychotic symptoms.
•    Proposed diagnostic criteria of APS:
A.    ≥ 1 of the following in attenuated form with relatively intact reality testing 
1.    Delusions
2.    Hallucinations
3.    Disorganized speech
B.    Symptom(s) must have been present at least once per week for the past month
C.    Symptom(s) must have begun or worsened in the past year
D.    It is sufficiently distressing and disabling to the individual
E.    It is not better explained by another mental disorder
F.    Criteria for any psychotic disorder have never been met.
Reference: 
i.    Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 1279
ii.    DSM-5 Manual

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman was brought to ER with physically aggressive behaviour towards her neighbour. On asking the patient, she reported that herself and her neighbour had a fight with each other a few days back following which she noticed that her neighbours are causing her to have electric shock like sensations. She reports that they can do this as they have planted a chip in her brain. The psychopathology described above is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Somatic Passivity
Solution:
Thought Alienation:
•    This is a disorder of possession of thoughts as the patient has the experience that their thoughts are under the control of an outside agency or that others are participating in their thinking.
•    Types of thought alienation:
1)    Thought insertion: In this the patient knows that thoughts are being inserted into their mind. 

    1. Thought withdrawal: Patient finds that they are thinking, their thoughts suddenly disappear and are withdrawn from their mind by foreign agency. It is an active process.
    2. Thought broadcast: Patient knows that others are getting to know their thoughts. It is a passive process.

Reference: Fish’s Clinical Psychopathology, 3rd edition, Page No 38

Somatic Passivity:

  • It is the belief that outside influences are playing on the body.
  • Patient believes that the somatic sensations are caused by foreign agency.

Reference: Sims’ Symptoms in the Mind, 6th edition, Page No 144

questions.text: A 23-year-old was a patient of Bipolar Affective Disorder and was maintaining well on Tab. Lithium 300 mg 1-0-3. He was brought to ER with 6-7 episodes of diarrhea. On examination, the patient had coarse tremors and was not orientated to time and place. Next step of management is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Stop lithium
Solution:
Lithium Toxicity:
•    Toxicity starts at 1.5 mEq/L
•    Mild to moderate toxicity:
    Occurs at serum lithium levels of 1.5 to 2 mEq/L
    Coarse tremors- 1st sign of lithium toxicity
    Abdominal pain, vomiting
    Ataxia, nystagmus
•    Moderate to severe toxicity:
    Occurs at serum lithium levels of 2 to 2.5 mEq/L
    Deep tendon reflexes- Hyperactive
    Delirium
•    Severe toxicity:
    Occurs > 2.5 mEq/L
    GTCS
    Oliguria
    Renal failure if serum lithium levels > 4 mEq/L
    Death
•    Management:
    1st step- Stop lithium
    Gastric lavage and activated charcoal
    Serum lithium levels
    If serum lithium levels > 4 mEq/L – Hemodialysis
Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 987

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented ER with dusky macules and blisters on skin. On examination, there was skin detachment seen. On asking the relatives, they said that the patient was started on a mood stabilizer 1 week back. Drug, most likely responsible is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Carbamazepine
Solution:
Above dermatological condition is suggestive of SJS/TEN which is most commonly associated with Lamotrigine. As Lamotrigine is not given in the options, the next best answer is Carbamazepine.
Carbamazepine:
•    Mechanism of action: Inhibition of Voltage sensitive sodium channels
•    Pharmacokinetics: It is an enzyme inducer i.e., stimulates CYP enzymes  induces its own metabolism [Autoinduction]
•    Excretion: Mainly by liver
•    Pre-carbamazepine tests:
1.    LFT mainly SGOT and SGPT
2.    Pregnancy test (Least teratogenic mood stabilizer]
•    Side effects: Mnemonic- SHADES
1.    S- SJS/TEN  maximum with Lamotrigine
2.    H- Hepatotoxic  most hepatotoxic: valproate
3.    A- Aplastic anemia
4.    D- Diplopia, ataxia (indicates cerebellar toxicity)
5.    E- Eosinophilia
6.    S- SIADH  Hyponatremia
•    Carbamazepine requires blood level monitoring. 
•    Blood concentration levels should be between 4-12 µg/mL.
•    LFT to monitored every 3 monthly
Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 959- 962

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl wakes in the middle of the night with a scream. On getting up, she was not aware of what happened and looked confused to her mother. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:

Night terror

Solution:

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page No 555 & 556

questions.text: A patient with polycystic ovarian syndrome will often have an increase in insulin resistance (commonly known as metabolic X syndrome). The subsequent menstrual irregularities are a result of an increase in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
Free testosterone level
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• The metabolic clearance rate (MCR) is defined as the volume of blood that is cleared of a substance per unit time. 
• The circulating level of a substance is determined by its blood production rate (PR) divided by its MCR. 
• With increased insulin resistance, insulin levels rise and inhibit hepatic production of SHBG. 
• As most circulating testosterone is bound to SHBG, a decrease in SHBG will increase the amount of free testosterone and decrease the amount of free estrogen. The free testosterone and levels of estrone from peripheral conversion of androstenedione will keep FSH levels low. 
•	The underlying insulin resistance augments the stimulatory action of LH on the growth and androgen secretion of ovarian theca cells.

questions.text: Given that prostaglandins (PGs) appear to be involved in preterm labor, which of the following medications might provide some help through interference with PG synthesis or release in stopping preterm labor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Indomethacin
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Indomethacin is an inhibitor of PG synthesis and is used as a tocolytic agent. Inhibitors of PG synthesis may be prescribed for pain relief during menstruation (dysmenorrhea), since PGs also play a role in dysmenorrhea. Although progesterone may be a tocolytic agent it does not appear to be mediated primarily through the PG cascade.

questions.text: Treatment modality shown in image below is related with management of?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
PCOD
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) is a common endocrinopathy, characterized by chronic anovulation, hyperandrogenism, and multiple small subcapsular cystic follicles in the ovary during ultrasonography, and affects 5–10% of women of reproductive age.
• PCOS is frequently associated with insulin resistance (IR) accompanied by compensatory hyperinsulinemia and, therefore, presents an increased risk of type 2 diabetes mellitus (DM). 
• The pathophysiology of PCOS is unclear, and many hypotheses have been proposed.
• Among these hypotheses, IR and hyperandrogenism may be the two key factors. The first line of treatment in PCOS includes lifestyle changes and body weight reduction. 
• Laparoscopic ovarian drilling has been widely accepted as the second line of choice for induction of ovulation in CC-resistant PCOS women in preference to gonadotrophin therapy.

choices.text: Ruptured corpus luteum cyst of the ovary

questions.text: A 23-year-old G1P1 patient is using barrier contraception and is 1 week past onset of her last mense. She is found to have bilaterally equal adnexal pain; cervical motion tenderness; direct abdominal tenderness; temperature, 101.3°F; and WBC, 12,000/mL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (b) 
PID 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
•	Although pelvic pain will be present in all the diagnoses listed, PID is most likely to produce symmetric, bilateral adnexal pain, abdominal pain, and cervical motion tenderness, along with an elevated temperature and WBC. 
•	The others tend to produce pain that is more severe on the affected side. 
•	Also, PID may flare as the menses is finishing.

questions.text: Compared to users of combination OCs, users of progestin-only OCs (minipills) are less likely to experience which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
Gonadotropin suppression
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Progestin therapy may be used for contraception by women who are nursing or unable to take estrogen (e.g., older women who smoke or who have other risk factors). 
• The progestin-only pill (the minipill) contains either norethindrone (0.35 mg) or norgestrel (0.075 mg). 
• Gonadotropin suppression is not as complete as that associated with OCs and use effectiveness is 2 to 3 pregnancies per 100 woman-years. 
• Ectopic pregnancy is not prevented as effectively as intrauterine pregnancy. Its use is associated with irregular vaginal bleeding, mood change, headache, amen-orrhea, and weight gain. 
• Other progestin-only contraception methods include intramuscular medroxyprogesterone acetate, subcutaneous levonorgestrel implants, and progestin-containing intrauterine device.

choices.text: The patient should begin her IVF treatment cycle.
The patient should repeat the HSG to confirm the result.
The patient should not be offered the opportunity to have IVF
Bilateral salpingectomies should be done prior to starting IVF

questions.text: A 31-year-old patient is preparing to start in vitro fertilization (IVF) because of obstructed fallopian tubes. On hysterosalpin-gogram (HSG), it is noted that she has large dilated hydrosalpinges present bilaterally. What should be your next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Bilateral salpingectomies should be done prior to starting IVF.
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
•	The bulk of the evidence in the current literature suggests that the presence of large hydrosalpinges decreased the pregnancy success rate of IVF by approximately 50%.
•	Thus, it is now standard practice to recommend bilateral resection of hydrosalpinges prior to initiating IVF to increase the couple’s chances of success. 
•	Aspirating the hydrosalpinges will simply result in refilling of the fallopian tubes with fluid.

choices.text: Ruptured corpus luteum cyst of the ovary

questions.text: A 16-year-old G0P0 patient reports delayed onset of menses, the sudden onset of severe pain, and syncope. A serum pregnancy test is negative. Her CBC reveals an Hct of 42% and a WBC of 8,000. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Ruptured corpus luteum cyst of the ovary
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• The sudden, severe pain is often associated with the rupture of a corpus luteum cyst. It may be accompanied by intra-abdominal hemorrhage. 
• Syncope is not uncommon. 
• Observation is generally all that is necessary for the patient. 
• Given the normal hematocrit and white blood count, an appendicitis is unlikely.

questions.text: Chemotherapy is recommended in post evacuation phase of molar pregnancy in all, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Regression of uterine size
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
Suction evacuation is the treatment of choice for molar pregnancy.
However, there are few conditions where it is necessary to give prophylactic methotrexate after suction evacuation. These include:
1.    hCG plateaus or rises in follow-up period
2.    Past history of vesicular mole
3.    Age >35 years
4.    Persistence of symptoms (vaginal bleeding, uterus does not regress back to normal size)
5.    Theca-lutein cysts more than 6 cm
6.    Pre-evacuation beta-hCG more than 1 lakh μIU/mL

questions.text: A 23-year-old woman (gravida 1, para 0), approximately 6 weeks pregnant, comes to your clinic for treatment. A home pregnancy test was positive 1 ½ weeks ago. She has developed bleeding over the past 2 days. What is the most likely cause of the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Abortion
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• The bleeding from any of these options may be profuse or minimal. 
• Abortion is the most common. 
• Up to one-third of all pregnancies are thought to end in early spontaneous abortion. 
• Uterine rupture is very unlikely to cause bleeding in the first trimester.

questions.text: An 84-year-old lady, with history of MI and on therapy for severe hypertension and cardiac failure, is also having procidentia. The ideal surgery for her is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)   
Le Fort’s repair
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
 Le Fort’s repair (complete colpocleisis) is done in very elderly postmenopausal women who are unfit for major surgery (medical complications such as heart failure, past history of myocardial infarction, severe hypertension, etc.), as the procedure can be performed under local anesthesia and sedation.
     Therefore, for this patient it is the ideal surgery.
 Prior to the procedure, PAP smear and pelvic USG should be done to rule out cervical dysplasia and pelvic pathology. Vaginal sexual activity is not possible after this surgery. If the patient is fit for surgery (no medical complications), then vaginal hysterectomy would be the ideal surgery.
 Cervicopexy is a conservative surgery for prolapse uterus, which is to be done only in young patients desirous of childbearing/menstrual function and not in menopausal women.
 Thiersch’s stitch is for rectal prolapse.

choices.text: Send the patient home on bed rest

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman (gravida 4, para 2, abortus 1) has been seen in the emergency department at 29 weeks’ gestation because of the sudden onset of painless vaginal bleeding that soaked four perineal pads and has now ceased. The mother’s vital signs and Hct are normal, and the FHTs are regular at 140 bpm. At this time, what should you do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B) 
Order an ultrasound examination
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Placenta previa must be ruled out, but this should not be done by pelvic examination at this time. 
• If a previa is present, a pelvic examination may precipitate massive bleeding, making cesarean section mandatory. 
• At 29 weeks’ gestation, the fetus has a good chance of survival if further insults do not occur. The placenta should be localized by ultrasound and expectant treatment instituted if placenta previa is found and no further severe bleeding occurs. 
• The limits of what constitutes acceptable blood loss are often hard to define and should be determined prospectively. Blood should be ordered and an IV started.

questions.text: A 31-year-old healthy woman (gravida 3, para 2) is in labor at 40 weeks’ gestation. Her first delivery was a low transverse cesarean for breech; the second was an uncomplicated VBAC. Her vital signs have been stable. Her epidural is functioning and she is lying on her side. When the cervix was approximately 7-cm dilated and the fetus was at –1 station, she developed tachycardia to 120 and a drop in blood pressure from 115/60 to 70/30. She has become dizzy upon sitting up. FHTs are 130. No bleeding is evident. The hematocrit is reported at 35%. What is your primary diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Ruptured uterus 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Although it is unusual for labor to persist with a ruptured uterus, it must be included in the differential. 
•  Vasa previa would cause immediate fetal distress. 
• Pulmonary complication and anesthetic complication are also possibilities but do not account for all the signs. 
• The mother has no apparent respiratory problems. 
• Supine hypotension should not occur on her side.

choices.text: Failure to excrete concentrated urine after 18 hours without fluids

questions.text: During late pregnancy, which of the following implies urinary tract disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Decreased creatinine clearance
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Because of increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR), serum creatinine is usually low during pregnancy and creatinine clearance is increased. 
• Decreased creatinine clearance may be seen in a variety of conditions such as preeclampsia and renal insufficiency. 
• The increased GFR is also responsible for glucosuria in gravidas with normal glucose levels. 
• The kidneys often excrete excess extracellular fluid after a period of recumbency, so the urine may not be concentrated after decreased oral intake of fluid, and urine is often the least concentrated in the morning. 
• There is usually normal dilation of the collecting system on IVP during pregnancy.

questions.text: Given finding on transabdominal pelvic ultrasound image is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)
Dichorionic Diamniotic Placenta
Ref: Read the text below    
Sol:
Twin Peak Sign or Lambda Sign:
• The twin peak sign (also known as the lambda (λ) sign) is a triangular appearance of the chorion insinuating between the layers of the intertwin membrane and strongly suggests a dichorionic twin pregnancy. 
• It is best seen in the first trimester (between 10-14 weeks) . 
• While the presence of a twin peak sign is a useful indicator of dichorionicity, its absence, however, is not that useful in confidently excluding it.

choices.text: Reattachment of the round ligaments to the vaginal cuff
Reattachment of the cardinal and uterosacral ligaments to the vaginal cuff
Complete a purse string suture closure of the cul-de-sac peritoneum

questions.text: When performing a vaginal hysterectomy for any indication, prevention of future enterocele or vaginal vault prolapse is aided by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C) 
Reattachment of the cardinal and uterosacral ligaments to the vaginal cuff
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Isolating the uterosacral and cardinal ligaments during the hysterectomy is important; so they can be used in the support of the vaginal vault. 
• Many people suture the uterosacral ligaments together to decrease the opening in the pouch of Douglas. 
• The vaginal mucosa has no inherent strength, but it is important to close the pubocervical and rectovaginal fascia underlying the vaginal mucosa. 
• The round ligaments are not considered a major support structure to the vaginal vault.
• While the peritoneum is often closed and is described in enterocele repairs, it is not the best procedure for reducing later prolapse.

choices.text: Oxytocin 10 units IM if bleeding exceeds 500 cc
Type and cross 2 units of packed red blood cells
Epidural anesthesia to facilitate manual removal of the placenta if needed
600 μg of prostaglandin E1 (misoprostol) given per rectum after delivery of the placenta

questions.text: In anticipation of a possible postpartum hemorrhage due to the prolonged induction and macrosomia, which of the following options is best for the prevention of excess blood loss?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
600 μg of prostaglandin E1 (misoprostol) given per rectum after delivery of the placenta
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• To prevent postpartum hemorrhage, the best method would be to give misoprostol per rectum. Waiting to give oxytocin is ill advised. 
• Oxytocin is best given at the time of delivery, and for this patient 10 units may be a small amount—an IV infusion would be a better option. Extra IV lines, and type and crossing blood, are important preparations but will not prevent a hemorrhage. 
• Use of methergine if there have been no hypertensive issues works well and through a different mechanism than the rhythmic contractions by oxytocin or prostaglandin medications.

choices.text: A genetic defect in ferritin synthesis

questions.text: A complete blood cell count is typically obtained at the initiation of prenatal care. This test is important as an indicator of general nutritional status. In the pregnant population, anemia can best be defined as which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
A hemoglobin below 11 g/dL 
Ref: Read the text below
Sol:
• Anemia is a common finding in pregnancy. 
• A fairly standard definition of anemia is important. In pregnancy, a hemoglobin below 10 g/dL is considered to reflect an anemic state. 
• The anemia may be partly “physiologic,” from the normal vascular volume increase with a great expansion of plasma volume than RBC mass, but it should and can be treated in most cases.

choices.text: Stop warfarin, start LMWH and asprin

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 36 weeks of gestation with a prosthetic valve replacement for mitral stenosis is on warfarin therapy. Her INR is 3. What is the appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The next appropriate step in the management of a pregnant woman with a prosthetic valve on warfarin therapy at 36 weeks of gestation is to stop warfarin and start low molecular weight heparin (LMWH).

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient was found to have uterus didelphys. Which of the following is not likely to be a complication of this uterine anomaly?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


Among the given options, transverse lie is not a likely complication of uterus didelphys. A transverse lie is more likely to be seen with an arcuate or sub-septate uterus.

questions.text: The ultrasound of a young woman with infertility is suggestive of a uterine anomaly. Which of the following is used to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Hysteroscopy + laparoscop

Hysteroscopy with laparoscopy is used to confirm the diagnosis. For infertility evaluation, hysteroscopy and laparoscopy can detect müllerian anomalies, screen for co-existent endometriosis, and exclude other tubal or uterine cavity pathology. Hysteroscopy combined with laparoscopy can confirm both the internal and the external contour of the uterus.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant woman, on examination was found to have infra-umbilical flattening. The fetal heart sounds were heard over the lateral side. What could be the fetal presentation/position?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Occipitoposterior

The presence of infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds on the lateral side indicates that the fetus is in the occipito-posterior position.

questions.text: A 28-year old pregnant woman came for a routine antenatal check-up in her second trimester. Four years back, she delivered 2 healthy full-term twins. What would her obstetric score be?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

G2P1

The obstetric score of a pregnant woman who previously delivered twins would be G2P1 (gravida 2 para 1).

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman on oral contraceptives for the past 6 months presents with 6 weeks of amenorrhea. What would be the best method of assessing the gestational age of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Crown rump length by USG

The best method of assessing the gestational age of a patient on oral contraceptives with weeks of amenorrhea is by measuring the crown-rump length (CRL) using ultrasonography. weeks.

choices.text: She is at significant risk for endometrial cancer
She is at increased risk for ovarian cancer
She is at increased risk for osteoporosis
She is at increased risk for multiple gestations

questions.text: A 32-year-old G1P1 woman presents with an 8-month history of amenorrhea. A pregnancy test is negative. TSH and prolactin levels are normal. The FSH level is elevated at 40 IU/L. Which of the following is the most likely complication for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

She is at increased risk for osteoporosis

This patient has secondary amenorrhea. Her pregnancy test is negative. The TSH and prolactin levels are normal. Her serum FSH level is elevated, indicating that she has premature ovarian failure. Due to the low estrogen levels, she is at risk for osteoporosis.

choices.text: Finding of a 9-cm right ovarian mass
Vaginal bleeding after a 5-day course of progesterone oral therapy

questions.text: A 32-year-old G0P0 woman is noted to have irregular menses and hirsutism. Which of the following is consistent with polycystic ovarian syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)


Women with PCOS usually will have a positive progestin challenge test; in other words, they have bleeding with a 5- to 10-day course of oral progestin.

choices.text: Dextrose 5% in 1/4 normal saline (DS ¼ NS)

questions.text: An 8-month-old infant is seen in the ED for diarrhea. The family reports that the child has had a 2-day history of nonbloody diarrhea and poor fluid intake. Triage vital signs show heart rate of 180 beats per minute, respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 60/40 mm Hg. On physical examination be has poor skin turgor, 5-second capillary refill, and cool extremities. Which of the following fluids is most appropriate first step in the management of this condition?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C)

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is seen in the physicians’ office for a laceration on this hand. The mother reports that he was at school when he became agitated and punched a wall. His past medical history reveals a diagnosis of mild autism and obsessive compulsive disorder for which he takes fluoxetine. He does poorly in special education classes at the local school. On physical examination the temperature is 37OC (98.5OF), heart rate is 74 beats per minute, respiratory rate 16 breaths per minute, and blood pressure of 110/64 mm Hg. Height and weight are 35th percentile, and the head circumference is 95th percentile. He has a long and thin face. The ears are large and protruding. The mucous membranes are moist and without lesions; the palate is arched and high. The chest is clear and with mild pectus excavatum. Heart has a normal S1 and S2 with a click over the mitral valve area. His phallus is normal in size and shape, and testes are enlarged. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
The physical features associated with the fragile X syndrome become more obvious after puberty, many of which are outlined in the case. They include macrocephaly, a long face, large ears, prominent jaw, high-arched palate, evidence of mitral valve prolapse, macroorchidism, pectus excavatum, hypotonia, repetitive speech, gaze avoidance, and hand flapping. Even in the absence of physical findings, boys of all ages with developmental delay, autism, and abnormal temperament of unknown cause probably should be tested for the fragile X syndrome.

questions.text: A 2-week-old neonate is seen in the pediatrician’s office with the maternal concern of poor feeding. The mother reports that since birth her bottle-fed newborn sleeps most of the day; she has to awaken her every 4 hours to feed and she will take only 50ml of formula at a time. She voids about twice a day and passes hard, pellet-like stools every other day. On physical examination growth parameters are at the 50th percentile for weight, length, and 95th percentile for head circumference. Temperature is 35OC (95OF), heart rate 75 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 35 breaths per minute. The newborn is jaundiced and somewhat difficult to awaken. The head is normocephalic with enlarged, flat anterior and posterior fontanels. Pupils are equally round and reactive to light; red reflex is normal. The chest has equal and unlabored breath sounds. Abdomen is soft, nontender, distended and with a large umbilical hernia. Which of the following is the most likely etiology for these findings?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)  
A. The clinical findings of congenital hypothyroidism are subtle, and may not be present at all at birth; this is thought to be a result of passage of some maternal T4 transplacentally. Neonates such as that in the vignette with examination findings will usually have an umbilical hernia and a distended abdomen. The head may be large, and the fontanelles will be large as well. The newborn may be hypothermic and have feeding difficulties; constipation and jaundice may be found in the genitals and extremities. The heart rate may be slow, and anemia may develop. Essentially all of these findings are presented in the case

questions.text: A 48-hour-old neonate in the normal newborn nursery develops deep cyanosis with crying. He was born vaginally at term to a 19-year-old mother with scant prenatal care. She reports no problems during the pregnancy. On physical examination vital signs and growth parameters are normal. Chest has good air movement without distress. Heart has increased apical impulse that is displaced to the left. Left ventricular impulse is prominent. The first heart sound is increased in intensity; the second heart sound is single. A 4 out of 6 holosystolic murmur along the left sternal border is found. Distal pulses are normal. Capillary refill time is less than 3 seconds. Abdomen is soft, nontender, and the liver is felt 3 cm below the costal margin. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
The patient in the question clearly has congenital heart disease. Patients with tricuspid atresia typically have a hypoplastic right ventricle, and therefore the ECG shows left-axis deviation and LVH; this translates to a left ventricular impulse on physical examination and likely notably diminished deflections of right ventricular forces. Additionally, right atrial overload may manifest as tall P waves in lead II. Almost all other forms of cyanotic congenital heart disease are associated with elevated pressures in the right ventricle and increased right ventricular impulse

choices.text: Short-acting bronchodilators and a 5-day course of steroids
Observation for hypoxia and dehydration alone
Inhaled epinephrine and a dose of steroids

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is seen in the emergency for cough and respiratory distress, the father reports that he was awakened in the middle of the night by his son who had developed noisy breathing on inspiration, respiratory distress, and a new barking cough. He has had an upper respiratory infection for the previous 2 days with nasal discharge, sneezing, and a mild, dry cough.   Past medical history is negative. His vaccines are current. On physical examination temperature is 38.4OC (101.1OF), heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 24 breaths per minute. Nose has clear nasal discharge. Ears canals are patents with translucent tympanic membranes. Chest has good, equal air movement, marked retractions of the chest wall and flaring of the nostrils. A prominent barking cough is heard. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 
Subglottic edema that develops as part of an upper respiratory tract infection results in the inspiratory stridor commonly heard with laryngotracheobronchitis (croup). The extrathoracic airway tends to collapse on inspiration, producing the characteristic findings this patient demonstrates; therapy usually is with a single dose of steroids. Agents causing croup include parainfluenza types 1 and 3, influenza A and B, RSV, and occasionally other viruses. Affected children are typically between the ages of 6 months and 5 years. Treatment is usually supportive, but racemic epinephrine and corticosteroids reduce the length of time in the emergency room and hospitalizations. Inspiratory stridor at rest and/or hypoxia are indications for admission and close observation

choices.text: Continued rapid volume expansion with one-fourth normal saline

questions.text:
A 4-month-old infant is seen by emergency room physician for a 3-day history of poor feeding, emesis, and diarrhea. She is given a fluid bolus via interosseous line, has subsequent urine output, and an intravenous line is obtained. Her care is transferred to the inpatient pediatric hospitalist team. Results from laboratories drawn in the ED are now available and show:

Sodium: 157 mEq/L

Potassium: 3.9 mEq/L

Chloride: 120 mEq/L

Bicarbonate: 14 mEq/L

Glucose: 195 mg/dL

Creatinine: 1.8 mEq/L

Blood urea nitrogen (BUN): 68 mEq/L

Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in her management?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
The infant in the question has had an emergency line placed for dehydration and has hypernatremic dehydration (high sodium, with elevated creatinine and low bicarbonate on the electrolyte panel). Initial bolus therapy in the emergency center should have been with isotonic fluid such as normal saline or lactated Ringer’s solution. Slow correction of this hypernatremia (0.5 mEq/L per hour over several days) prevents significant fluid shifts in the brain that may result in increased intracranial pressure and herniation. Hyperglycemia may be seen in hypernatremic dehydration because of deceased insulin secretion and cell sensitivity to insulin; this is particularly important to recognize because an increased serum glucose can cause the serum sodium lab result to be falsely decreased. Blood products such as fresh-froze plasma are not indicated, and rapid infusion of hypotonic solution such as D10W and one-fourth normal saline could cause rapid fluid shifts resulting in cerebral edema and death. Hypertonic (3%) saline is used only in the event of seizures caused by rapid rehydration (or in children with hyponatremic dehydration and associated central nervous system symptoms), along with other emergent measures typically used to reduce cerebral edema

choices.text: Nephrotic syndrome due to minimal change disease

questions.text: A 7-year old presents to your office for puffy eyes. Her past history is significant for attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) for which she takes a stimulant medicine, and an upper respiratory tract infection that resolved the previous week. Her blood pressure is 97/57 mm Hg, heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and respiratory rate is 18 breaths per minute. A careful physical examination reveals bilateral orbital, labial, and ankle edema. Her examination is otherwise normal. You obtain a urinalysis that reveals 4+ protein, without leukocytes or blood, and her serum creatinine is 0.2 mg/dL. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D) 

Nephrotic syndrome is a constellation of findings that can be seen in glomerular disease. The classic triad of symptoms includes hypoalbuminemia, edema, and hyperlipidemia, all related to the underlying problem of large urinary loses of protein. ‘’ Nephrotic-range” proteinuria is defined as more than 40 mg/m2/h or a protein-to-creatinine ratio of more than 2:1. While there are many causes of nephrotic syndrome (including malignancy, malaria, drugs infections, and metabolic conditions), children most commonly have primary, or idiopathic, nephrotic syndrome. Minimal change disease is the most common glomerular lesion associated with idiopathic nephrotic syndrome, and 90% of children with minimal changes disease respond well to steroids.

The glomerulonephritis presents with edema and proteinuria, but also with hypertension, hematuria, and renal insufficiency. HUS usually presents after diarrhea caused by a toxin producing strain of Escherichia coli

questions.text: A 21-year-old woman has just delivered a term infant. She has had only one visit to her obstetrician, and that was at about 6 weeks of pregnancy. She provides her laboratory results from that visit. The delivered infant is microcephalic, and has cataracts, a heart murmur, and hepatosplenomegaly. Your further evaluation of the neonate demonstrates thrombocytopenia, mild hemolytic anemia, and on the echocardiogram, patent ductus arteriosus and peripheral pulmonary artery, stenosis. Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this neonate’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

When German measles (rubella) occurs during the first 2 months of pregnancy, it has a severe effect on the fetus, including cardiac defects, cataracts, and glaucoma. The most common cardiac defects are patent ductus arteriosus, which can be accompanied by peripheral pulmonary artery stenosis, and atrial and ventricular septal defects. Myriad other complications vary in incidence with the timing of the infection during pregnancy, including thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and deafness (sensorineural).

choices.text: Loss of the paternally inherited allele of chromosome 15q11
Loss of the maternally inherited allele of chromosome 15q11

questions.text: A 14-year-old boy is seen in the weight management clinic as a referral from a pediatric pulmonologist who has diagnosed him with sleep apnea. His foster family knows little of his history other than he has relatively poor school performance. On physical examination his weight is well over the 99th percentile and his height is at the 10yh percentile. He has almond-shaped eyes and strabismus. His abdomen is obsess with a well-healed scar on the left side. He has small hands and feet, and is tanner stage 1 with overall hypogenitalism. His condition is most likely related to which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
The child in the question likely has Prader-Willi

questions.text: The baseline incidence of congenital heart disease is about 1%. For a family with a child with isolated congenital heart disease, the incidence of heart disease in future children is which of the following?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B)

questions.text: What radiological sign is used to describe a tension pneumocephalus?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)
Aren't radiology signs a bit silly? Anyway, the correct answer is Mt Fuji sign describing the compressed and separated frontal poles in a pneumocephalus.  The importance is not the name of the sign, but the appearance, as urgent decompression is required

questions.text: Which type of cerebral herniation can result in occlusion of the ipsilateral posterior cerebral artery?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)
Transtentorial herniation, most commonly uncal, but also potentially ascending (due to posterior fossa mass effect) can occlude the posterior cerebral artery and/or superior cerebellar artery resulting in infarction.

questions.text: Which label identifies the ascending thoracic aorta?
questions.solution:

1 is mark at ascending aorta

questions.text: Which label identifies the insertion of the biceps brachii tendon?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)
1
The biceps brachii muscle (also known simply as biceps) is a two-headed muscle in the anterior compartment of the arm that flexes at the elbow and supinates the forearm. It inserts into the radial tuberosity of the proximal radius
